scenes.location: LAND ROVER/EXT. LARGE CONSTRUCTION SITE NIGHT 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window of a Land Rover, we see a construction site working at full capacity. Huge arc lights and floodlights illuminate the scene and men are hard at work A group of men are in discussion in a pool of light. Ther is a conversation, then one of the men breaks off and tak call on his cellphone. He is distant, not even the focal point of the shot. He puts his finger in his ear to hear call more clearly. He is too far away for us to see his reactions or expression but, when he cuts the call, he wa directly toward the car and the other men turn to watch h go. As he gets closer we see he wears a tie and heavy boots a heavy coat. He wears a hard hat. He finds a key fob and hits it. The lights inside the car glow in response. The man gets into the driver’s seat. He is in his thirtie a face made of stone and unused to expressions of emotion This is IVAN LOCKE. He sits in the driver’s seat for a few moments. He takes breath and we might guess (or we might not) that he has j had some important news. Is he scared, angry? He takes out his cellphone and looks, deciding whether or to make a call. He checks his watch. He decides there isn time for the call. He puts the phone away quickly and fir the engine. He shifts gear and reverses. We stay with him and will st with him intensely for the rest of the story. The car bumps over rough ground as Ivan heads for the big secure gates that open out onto the street. The construct site is massive and it takes a while to reach the edge of Trucks rumble and generators roar. This is Ivan’s world. The gates are opened by a guy in a high viz jacket. Ivan reaches the kerb of the road and indicates right as a ref But he doesn’t pull away. He realizes that this time he must choose which way he wi go. He has a decision to make but he is a man who makes a hundred hard decisions a day. Even so, he takes time. A massive truck pulls up inches behind him and its headli fill Ivan’s car. Ivan continues to make his decision as h indicator ticks away the seconds. The truck hoots its baleful horn, the voice of fate. Ivan hits the indicator to indicate left instead of right He turns left and joins light evening traffic.  Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Ivan pulling out of the site through the lens of a CCTV camera...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ivan will now drive through city streets toward the M6 motorway, a couple of miles away. We will not blink as we study him as he drives... Ivan is now confronting the crisis in his head. On the si he was in a familiar place but now he is on a journey and must necessarily begin to consider the destination and th place he is leaving. His first decision is to make a phone call on his hands f car phone. This is an important component of the story so should take some time establishing the mechanism. He has long list of speed dial numbers, identified by names or locations. He speed dials a number labelled ‘Bastard’...

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: Hello, can I speak to Gareth? We hear a woman’s voice from the hands-free phone. Many voices will come into the car during this story. The firs is a woman in her forties (GARETH’S WIFE)... GARETH’S WIFE (OOV) He’s not back yet. Can I ask who’s calling?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: Ivan Locke. GARETH’S WIFE (OOV) Can I say what it’s regarding?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: Concrete. Ivan takes a moment and decides an explanation would be pointless...

dialogues.speaker: IVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you tell him it’s urgent and tell him to call me back. GARETH’S WIFE (OOV) Does he have your number?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: Yes.  Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 4. We hear children in the background and a TV. Ivan reacts the family sounds because the world of children and famil about to explode and he will be cut adrift from it foreve GARETH’S WIFE (OOV) What was your name again?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: Ivan Locke. GARETH’S WIFE (OOV) Something about concrete.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: Yes. GARETH’S WIFE (OOV) Will he know what?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: No. Something has come up. I need to tell people... Ivan almost chokes on some unexpected emotion. It is a sh to us and to him, like undigested food hitting his gullet

dialogues.speaker: IVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s urgent. A dog barks. GARETH’S WIFE (OOV) What?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: I said it’s very urgent. Thanks. He cuts the call and drives. The emotion that just struck him was a bad development so early. He has a lot to do in the next hour and a half and he must hold this together a all costs. He drives for a while to calm himself. Then, when he is sure he is ready, he makes another call... We hear a mobile phone answer message. The voice is BETHA early thirties... BETHAN’S ANSWER MESSAGE (OOV) Hi, this is Bethan. I can’t get to the phone right now, please leave a message. Ivan misses the cue of the beep by a second because he’s getting his voice straight. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: It’s Ivan. I got your messages. I’m on my way and I’‘1l get there. I’m in the car now. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 5

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’ll be about an hour and a half unless there’s traffic. He takes a moment... IVAN LOCKE (CONT’D) It’ll be ok. If the nurses or anybody wants to talk to me I’m only on this number. Or if the doctors or anybody. It’1ll be ok. I‘ll get there. The traffic should be ok. He cuts the call. He drives and twenty seconds later his phone rings... IVAN LOCKE (CONT’D) Ivan Locke. We hear a soft Southern Irish accent... A pause. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: I just got your message. It’s a joke, is it?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: I know it’s a shock but it will be ok?

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (INCREDULOUS)
dialogues.text: Ok?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: I will go through everything with you and it’1ll be ok.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: You know where I am? I’m ata service station. I’m turning the fucking van round. I put the other lads out on the hard shoulder. I was halfway home.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: What the fuck happened?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: It's a family thing.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Is someone...  He pauses. Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 6.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Is it a bereavement?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: I don’t have a choice...

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Is it one of the kids?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Donal, I need you to just fix this up and be alright... IVAN LOCKE (CONT’D) And solid. Which you are. Which you are. Just from when the sun comes up tomorrow morning until when it’s all been pumped. I need you to hold it together. You won’t be alone. I can be on the phone. I‘1l talk to you every five minutes until the pump is finished...

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: On the fucking phone?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: On the phone.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Have you gone mad?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (RUNNING ON)
dialogues.text: Ivan, at 5.45am tomorrow morning we have three hundred and fifty metric tons of wet concrete being delivered to our site. We have two hundred trucks from all over the fucking country descending on us...

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE, (CORRECTING)
dialogues.text: Three hundred and fifty five metric tons, two hundred and eighteen trucks. A disbelieving pause. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: It's a joke. Is it?  Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 7

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: I have no choice.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Is it a bereavement? Ivan never lies. Silence. A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Ivan, what the fuck has happened?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: I need you to just do this. A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Ivan, I hate myself even hearing myself even saying this, but if someone’s died like your mother or someone, could you not go wherever you have to go after twelve tomorrow when the concrete is pumped? Ivan drives...

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: You know what I’m saying. Whoever is dead is not...you know...they won't be any different between now and midday. Dead people stay the same.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: No one is dead. Donal, I need you to do this, ok? I need you to be there with enough stuff and the right heads when the sun comes up.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Holy fucking Mary. I’m a fucking concrete farmer. Did you ever see me read anything written down on paper.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: You’re ok. You know how to run a pump, you know how to run trucks back-to-back and turn trucks back, you know how to test for slumps.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: I’ve never even shovelled on a pump this big...  Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 8

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: It’s the same but more of it. You just do the same but for longer. Check it, slump it, send it back if it’s piss and pump it if its right. A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: What did Gareth say?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: I haven’t spoken to him yet.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: He’1ll fucking...

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: I know...

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: He’ll go fucking sideways and around the houses like his arse is on fire.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Ivan, it’1ll be the sack.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Jesus, you’re the best foreman I ever fucking worked with and the best site manager. What the hell is it that’1ll make you risk the sack?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: I need you to do this for me Donal. Start rounding up some cowboys then call me back. I'’11 be on the road. He cuts the call. Ivan is a strong practical man and he i facing a crisis which is unfamiliar, but some things he c keep control of. Men like Donal he can handle. He drives some more but ten seconds later the phone rings...

dialogues.speaker: IVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ivan Locke.

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Ivan?  Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 9

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Where are you? When Bethan speaks she sounds scared to death and in pain She’s mid-forties, middle class...

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: I just got admitted. I’m in the labor ward. It’s called Bailey ward.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Did they say how long?

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: I'm five centimetres.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Dilated.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: I know but what does that mean? How long?

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: They just left me. I’m on my own.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Is there a bell?

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: I don’t know, a buzzer or something to get a nurse.

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: They just put their head round. They said it could be hours. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Are you ok?

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: I need the lavatory...

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Tell them. Tell them.

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: There’s no one here.  He stops. A pause. Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 10.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Is there a bell?

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: They don’t have bells. What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: When they put their head round the door, tell them you need the lavatory.

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: It’s like a pain I’ve never had. Right inside all the way up to my chest.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Have you talked to anyone about pain?

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Stopping the pain. Have you decided.

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: They said ‘let’s see’.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Just have whatever there is. Seriously.

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. For the pain. Because fuck...

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: You were there when your wife gave birth.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Don’t think about that, get them to give you everything. If they ask, just say I want everything.

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: What did she have?  Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 11. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Your precious wife. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: I can’t remember. The thing they put in your spine. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Were you there?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: And you'll be here...

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Because I’m really in pain... She begins to cry. Ivan drives on through the night.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: The traffic’s ok. Just tell them to give you everything for the pain. I‘ll be there in an hour and a half. If anything happens, just shout as loud as you can.

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: It’s cold and all the windows are open.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Tell them to close the windows. The traffic’s ok. Go to the lavatory. I'll be there. She begins to sob and we hear a whimper of pain.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE, (SOFTLY TO HIMSELF)
dialogues.text: (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck. A pause.  Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 12.

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Have you even told your wife that someone is having your baby? He drives....

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: I’m about to do that. I have a list of things I have to do tonight while I’m driving.

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: So I’m on a list.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Tonight, yes. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Do you love me? A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: That’s a question you’re asking probably because of the pain or something. How could I love you? The call is cut. Ivan drives on. He speaks softly to himself as he glances in the rear view mirror and sees hi own eyes... IVAN LOCKE (CONT’D) So. Hell. He must concentrate on the road. He flicks through his sp dial numbers and finds ‘HOME’. He is about to call but th phone rings.... IVAN LOCKE (CONT’D) Ivan Locke.

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (OOV)
dialogues.text: It’s Gareth. I spoke to Donal. This had better be more than good.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Hello Gareth...

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (INTERRUPTING, FURIOUS)
dialogues.text: Speak to me only about the morning. It is apparent Gareth has already heard the news but Ivan confirms.  Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 13.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: I won’t be on site for the pump tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (TO HIMSELF)
dialogues.text: This is not happening.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: The truth is tonight I’m going to become a father. A long pause. IVAN LOCKE (CONT’D) She’s in London. I have to be there.

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Ok, ok, ok, let me read you something. Ivan. Are you listening? Yeah? Good. It’s from Mr Dean in Chicago. ‘Good luck tomorrow with the pour. We have just had it confirmed by CGO that this will be the biggest single concrete pour ever made in Europe outside of nuclear/military projects. I know the day is in the safest of hands. Best wishes, Mitchell.’ That’s Mitchell Dean himself. The President of the whole fucking company. Did you hear that Ivan? From Chicago. USA.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (OOV)
dialogues.text: You’1l have to speak up.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: Yes, I heard.

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (OOV)
dialogues.text: And you're the man in charge of the entire operation but, with ten hours to go, you've decided you won't be there.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Donal will handle it. He is a good man.

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (EXPLODING)
dialogues.text: Don’t you fucking dare say that to me. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 14.

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (EXPLODING)
dialogues.text: Don’t fucking dare to give qualitative appraisals of my staff and say ‘good man’ like it’s going off to buy a fucking ice cream. Ivan drives. A pause...

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (OOV)
dialogues.text: This is fucking concrete. Like shit. Like piss when it comes, you pump it.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Like babies.

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (OOV)
dialogues.text: It's a joke to you.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: No. Right now nothing is a joke anymore.

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (OOV)
dialogues.text: So it’s not your wife giving birth?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: No it’s someone else.

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (INCREDULOUS)
dialogues.text: Jesus. Ivan? You are the last person on earth...

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Yes. I am the last person on earth. But it happened.

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (OOV)
dialogues.text: And this woman can’t give birth on her own?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: I've made a decision. There is nobody else who could be with her. She has no friends in London and is a quite fragile person.

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (SNARLING)
dialogues.text: Fragile? Ivan drives...

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (OOV)
dialogues.text: You’re going to abandon the biggest fucking concrete pour in Europe to hold someone’s fucking hand because she’s fragile.  Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 15.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: And because the baby was caused by me. That is the decision I have made. I have not behaved in the right way with this woman. At all. I have behaved in a way that isn’t like me. But now I am going to do the right thing.

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (OOV)
dialogues.text: And Chicago can go to fucking hell.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: It is the decision I have made. I’m not going to turn back.

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Jesus, Jesus, Jesus. You know how many million pounds are riding on tomorrow?... Ivan drives...

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (OOV)
dialogues.text: If any one of those pumps fucks up we are facing ten million pounds worth of losses in fifteen minutes. So we get that every fifteen minutes for the whole morning, a total shut down, hundred million dollars. Pumping the hard stuff into soft ground and watching it set so we have to pay another fucking gang of fucking Hungarian monkeys to dig it out again. Secondary cost, outside insurance, another five million. Ivan drives.

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Are you still there?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Yes. I have no explanation apart from the one I have given. I must do the right thing by this woman. A pause. Gareth is about to speak... IVAN LOCKE (CONT’D) But, Gareth, I have made a pledge to myself that I will not allow the pour to fuck up.

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (OOV)
dialogues.text: This is a joke. Are you wearing a fucking red nose?  Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 16. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (OOV)
dialogues.text: This is a fucking joke. I’m going to call Chicago. If it weren’t for the fact that you’ve been so solid for us for so many years I would fire you down the phone. Ivan drives...

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (OOV)
dialogues.text: But I will speak to Chicago first. Silence...

dialogues.speaker: GARETH, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Ivan? Have you lost your fucking mind? Ivan checks his rear view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: I made my decision. The call is cut. Ivan drives on as he considers the question. Has he lost his mind? We come close to his face as he considers his situation. Then he glances in the rear view mirror. We sense that something in the mirror bothers him, an irritant he tries ignore but finally can’t. He snaps into the rear view mirror... IVAN LOCKE (CONT’D) What the fuck are you looking at? A pause. IVAN LOCKE (CONT’D) You’re watching this aren’t you. Laughing at my predicament? A familiar predicament to a man like you, right dad? A pause. IVAN LOCKE (CONT’D) You think ‘there he is, look. Like father like son. The man I made’. A pause. IVAN LOCKE (CONT’D) What is it they say? The apple doesn’t fall far from the tree. Well that’s where you’re wrong.  Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 16A. He studies the road, the lights flashing across his face.  Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 17. Ivan erupts slowly... IVAN LOCKE (CONT’D) You listen to me you fucking piece of worthless shit. I want you to watch... A pause. His face harder and harder... IVAN LOCKE (CONT’D) In fact I’d like to take a fucking shovel and dig you up out of the fucking ground and make you watch me tonight. He stares into the mirror. IVAN LOCKE (CONT’D) I'd pull open your eyes and kick the mud and worms and shit out your ears. Just for the duration of this fucking journey. Because it’s me driving not you. He drives on but his face fixes with determination.... IVAN LOCKE (CONT’D) And unlike you I‘’1ll go to the place where I should be and I’11 be there to take care of my fuck up. I’11 take what’s due to me. He glares into the rear view mirror... IVAN LOCKE (CONT’D) So you laugh or do what the fuck you want, like you always do, but I’ll fix this. Pause. IVAN LOCKE (CONT’D) I’ll fix it. His phone rings. He glances at the ghost of his father wi venom. IVAN LOCKE (CONT’D) Yes Donal.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Ok, I’m driving back so I’1l be quick. I called Ryan and stole a half dozen Poles and some Hungarians from Patrick. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 17A.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: I got breakfast tickets for the concrete farmers and the shutter boys are done bar the fucking about with clips. I asked Albanian Alby to test the pumps on the Argylle side and he said they’re pissing it out.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Ok, ok stop. When you get back on site you check every pump yourself, individually and with your own hand on the turner. You don’t ask anybody else to check and sign off. You go around the whole site and you check each one yourself. And don’t trust Alby after five because he drinks. Now. Talk to me about the mix.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Did we say C6? Ivan reacts...

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Don’t say that like it’s a question.  Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 18.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Sometimes when I say things it sounds like a question when it isn’t.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: All the mixes for this pump will be C6. Why do you even ask? It’s written on the whiteboard in fucking giant letters. I put ‘C6’ all over the cabin in big red letters. Slump of one inch, Cé. Don’t ask me questions like that...

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: It wasn’t a question. I know you don’t like questions.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: What time are you unlocking?

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: I’m going to sleep here tonight.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Good. Except, don’t sleep. Check everything. You’ve got the client sign-off.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Yeah. And the client sign-off on the gates.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: That’s what I mean. The gate sign off. Donal, the construction sign off should already be filed.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s ok. That’s what I meant. Ivan reacts....

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Ok, you have the phone numbers of the plants. Call them now Donal. Call every one of the bastards and get them to repeat the order. C6 on the nose or we send the trucks back. Seriously. Those bastards will fuck you up with water in the gulleys if it rains tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: DONAL, (OOV)

dialogues.text: Two words I learnt tonight. ‘Fuck Chicago’. Ivan cuts the call. He drives and we stay with him for a long time. A minute goes by. Then a call comes in and Iva reads ‘unknown’. As the call rings, Ivan decides he canno take it. His voicemail message clicks in.  Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 70. IVAN LOCKE’S VOICEMAIL (OOV) This is Ivan Locke. Please leave a message. Ivan hears the voice of Eddie and Eddie leaves a message.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Dad, I’m on my mobile. I’m under the duvet. I wanted to tell you about the goal. Eddie is fighting a terrible upset by trying to behave th way he behaved before this happened.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Caldwell got it and he controlled it. You know how you always shout at him because it always flies off him and out into the crowd? Well, he controlled it. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (OOV)
dialogues.text: And he got it down on the ground. You know how you say he just lumps it forward all the time, well he got it down on the ground. This is Caldwell, dad. And he just started running... Eddie begins to laugh and cry at the same time...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (OOV)
dialogues.text: And he was running and running and running and these defenders were bouncing off him. Eddie laughs...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (OOV)
dialogues.text: And he went round one, then another, and me and Sean were standing up and shouting at him to pass the ball. You know how you say you have to square it. He wouldn’t square it. He wouldn’t pass. He just kept running. He looked like a horse or something. Eddie laughs again.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (OOV)
dialogues.text: So then the goalie is coming forward and we think he’s going to boot it over the bar. Remember against whoever it was when he just booted it over the bar. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (OOV)
dialogues.text: We thought it was going to be that again. But he didn’t. This is Caldwell dad. The one you say is always a donkey. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (OOV)
dialogues.text: He went round the goalie and put it in. A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Mum was crying so she didn’t even see it. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (OOV)
dialogues.text: But we recorded it for you so you have to come home to watch it. You’1ll have to come home and I’ve had an idea. We'll pretend we don’t know the score and pretend it’s happening then. Pretend it’s live. And me and Sean will go mad the same. You can have the beer and mum can make the sausages. A pause. Eddie concludes quickly.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (OOV)
dialogues.text: So that’s what we’1ll do. Good night dad. The call is cut. Ivan drives on. He drives for a long tim and wipes his eyes with his sleeve. Then his phone rings. We see ‘Unknown’. Ivan hesitates th takes the call.

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (HISSING)
dialogues.text: Ivan?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Is it ok?

dialogues.speaker: BETHAN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: It’s a boy. Ivan reacts. BETHAN (OOV) (CONT’D) Listen...  20 Locke - Shooting Script - Feb 21st 2013 72. We hear the sound of a baby crying down the phone. The th sound fills the car and Ivan lets the car slow down on it own. Horns hoot and Ivan drifts onto the hard shoulder. The car comes to a halt. The sound of the baby crying continues. Ivan knocks the car out of gear and switches o the engine. A silence around the sound of the baby crying Ivan listens and glances in the rear view mirror. Then he puts his head on the steering wheel and the sound of the crying continues. He sits with his head on the steering wheel for a long ti Then... BETHAN (OOV) (CONT’D) Ivan, will you come?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN LOCKE
dialogues.text: Yes. He cuts the call. He is alone in silence for a few moment Was the birth of a new life worth the destruction of his Is there redemption in this moment? Ivan doesn’t have an answer. After a moment he fires the engine.

dialogues.text: From a surveillance camera we see Ivan’s car indicate the pull out into the traffic. After Ivan’s car has gone, we watch the other cars on their own journeys, all of them w their own stories inside their bubbles of light.
